Package tools.concurrent

Class TimerTool

  • java.lang.Object
    • tools.concurrent.TimerTool
  • public class TimerTool
extends java.lang.Object
    Class which adds extra functionallity to the default Timer class. The added functionalities are:
    • Changing the update interval. Keeps the same task running. Can be set via interval or updates per second (fps).
    • Pausing a timer. A paused timer will, after being resumed, continue as if it wasn't paused. So if the next update is over 500ms before being paused, then after being resumed the next update will occur over 500ms. If the update interval was decreased with dt while the timer was paused, then the next update will occur over max(0, 500-dt).
    • Canceling a timer. After a timer has been canceled, it can be started again with the same settings.
    • Manual and automatic frame rate handeling. In manual mode, a target interval is set and the updates occur after every interval time. If the previous update was still running, then the current update is ignored.
      In automatic mode, a target interval is set and AIMD is used to prevent clashing update cycles.
    • Starting a timer which is already started does nothing.
    • Resuming a timer which is already started or canceled does nothing.
    • Pausing a timer which is already paused or canceled does nothing.
    • Canceling a timer which is already canceled does nothing.
    This class is suitable for concurrent access.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TimerTool

        public TimerTool​(java.lang.Runnable... rs)
        Creates a timer with no initial delay and runs at 1 second intervals.
        Parameters:
        rs - The actions that will be executed when the timer ends.

      • TimerTool

        public TimerTool​(long interval,
                 java.lang.Runnable... rs)
        Creates a timer with no initial delay and runs at the given interval.
        Parameters:
        rs - The actions that will be executed when the timer ends.
        interval - The time in ms which is between two executions of r.run().

      • TimerTool

        public TimerTool​(long delay,
                 long interval,
                 java.lang.Runnable... rs)
        Creates a new timer with the given delay and interval, which will run the given runnables as tasks.
        Parameters:
        rs - The actions that will be executed when the timer ends.
        interval - The time in ms which is between two executions of r.run().

      • TimerTool

        public TimerTool​(long delay,
                 long interval,
                 boolean isDaemon,
                 java.lang.Runnable... rs)
        Creates a new timer with the given delay and interval, which will run the given runnables as tasks. The times will run as daemon only if == true
        Parameters:
        rs - The actions that will be executed when the timer ends.
        delay - The time in ms before the first exectution of r.run().
        interval - The time in ms which is between two executions of r.run().
        isDaemon - Whether the created times will be daemon or not. The default is true.

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the timer.
        Does nothing if the timer is already running or paused.

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Pauses the timer.
        Does nothing if the timer is paused or stopped.

      • resume

        public void resume()
        Resumes a paused timer.
        Does nothing if the timer is running or canceled.

      • cancel

        public void cancel()
        Cancels a timer.
        Does nothing if the timer is canceled.

      • setInterval

        public void setInterval​(long interval)
        Sets a new interval for the timer.
        Parameters:
        interval - The new interval to be set.

      • setFPS

        public void setFPS​(double fps)
        Sets the interval using frame rates. Uses setInterval(long) for the implementation.
        Parameters:
        fps - The new fps.

      • setTargetInterval

        public void setTargetInterval​(long interval)
        Sets the target interval. When using the auto-fps mode, this value will be used even when a shorter interval is possible. Also sets the current interval to the target interval to improve convergence.
        Parameters:
        interval - The new target interval.

      • setTargetFPS

        public void setTargetFPS​(double fps)
        Sets the target frame rate.
        Parameters:
        fps - The new target frame rate.

      • getInterval

        public long getInterval()
        Returns:
        The current interval between two updates.

      • getFPS

        public double getFPS()
        Returns:
        The current number of frames per second.

      • setFPSState

        public void setFPSState​(FPSState state)
        Sets the state for handeling the frame rate.
        Parameters:
        state - The new state.

      • getFPSState

        public FPSState getFPSState()
        Returns:
        The current state for handeling the frame rate.

      • getState

        public TimerTool.TimerState getState()
        Returns:
        The current state of the timer.
